bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Dean Acheson, January 12, 1953

div1.p: Hench thanks Secretary of State Acheson for the help his department provided in regards to the Camp Lazear dedication.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Dean Acheson, January 12, 1953
div1.opener:
January 12, 1953
The Honorable Dean Acheson
Secretary of State
Washington, D. C.
Dear Mr. Secretary:
div1.p:
I wish to express to you the very sincere appreciation of myself and other
Americans for the important services which one of your departmental
associates, Mr. Willard Beaulac, United States Ambassador to Cuba, rendered
last month when the Cuban Government dedicated “Camp Lazear Memorial Park”
(named for the American physician-martyr, Dr. Jesse Lazear) near Havana.

Ambassador Beaulac's extremely helpful support on that occasion was of
much greater importance than one not familiar with the historical sig-
nificance of Camp Lazear or of the past and recent Cuban attitude toward
Major Walter Reed and his associates would realize.

The participation in the Cuban ceremonies by Ambassador and Mrs. Beaulac
and by four of his Embassy Staff (Mr. Earl Crain - First Secretary;
Colonel Robert J. Mason - Air Attache; Lt. Colonel Vincent Elmore - Army
Attache; Major Harold Lampner - U. S. Army Medical Corps) constituted an
important diplomatic act as far as the Cuban people were concerned, and
represented also a real service to the Medical Corps of the United States
Army and to the American medical profession, in other words, to two large
and important American organizations.

The friendly dignity exhibited by Ambassador Beaulac and his colleagues on
this occasion which was one of special significance to the Cuban Government,
medical profession and people (especially to certain sensitive elements
thereof), was deeply appreciated by the Cubans and was responsible for a
number of very sympathetic articles in the Cuban press which noted the
supreme importance of the Cuban-American scientific cooperation responsible
for the eradication of yellow fever, and the continuing good will existing
between our two countries.

On this occasion for the first time, the Cuban Government, spending Cuban
money, publicly honored the “American” conquerors of yellow fever (Major
Walter Reed, Drs. James Carroll, Jesse Lazear, Aristides Agramonte and
their soldier-volunteers), joining their names (in bronze memorials) with
that of their illustrious Dr. Carlos Finlay, “the symbol of Cuban science.”
The official support of the American diplomatic representatives in Cuba
The Honorable Dean Acheson
- 2 -
January 12, 1953
was vital for the success of the affair. I and the many other Americans
concerned are indeed grateful for the sympathetic interest and able co-
operation which your department, in the person of Ambassador Beaulac and
his staff, rendered on that occasion.
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
